abstract.para: This chapter presents a grouping of the PHPlot functions by category. Descriptions of the functions can be found in .

sect1.title: Core
sect1.para: The functions in this section form the core of PHPlot. You cannot produce plots without using these. If you want to produce plots with little or no customization, you need use no other functions. These functions are used to create a PHPlot object, select the type of plot you want, provide the data to be plotted, and output the plot.

sect1.title: Input/Output Control
sect1.para: The functions in this section control the overall input and output of the plot. Use the functions in this section to select the graphics file format, direct the output, and control browser caching.

sect1.title: Colors and Line Styles
sect1.para: The functions in this section are used to control the colors and line styles of PHPlot elements. More information about using colors in PHPlot can be found in .

sect1.title: Additional Style Controls
sect1.para: The functions in this section control additional style attributes of the plot, including background images, borders, point style and size for point plots, and shading for 3D affects.

sect1.title: Error Bar Controls
sect1.para: The functions in this section control the appearance of error bars, used in plots with plot data type data-data-error.
See also , which sets the color used for error bars.

sect1.title: Text Fonts
sect1.para: The functions in this section control the text fonts used by PHPlot. PHPlot supports both built-in GD fonts and TrueType fonts (if available on your system). PHPlot does not support Adobe Type1 fonts, even if your GD supports them. See for more information about font selection.

tip.para: TrueType fonts produce generally higher quality text, but using them requires more internal computations. The built-in GD fonts are faster to render, but are limited to one typeface and 5 available sizes. TrueType fonts can be any size and angle, and many typefaces are available. On most systems, TrueType fonts are anti-aliased for improved appearance, but under some conditions the GD fonts may be easier to read.

sect1.title: Titles
sect1.para: The functions in this section set the title strings: the overall plot title, and optional titles for the X and Y axes.
See also to set the title colors, and to set the title fonts.

sect1.title: Legend
sect1.para: The functions in this section control the legend, which is an optional element on the plot. A legend is usually used to identify each plot line or set of points when a plot contains multiple data sets. A legend can also be used with pie charts to identify the sections.
See also to set the legend text color, to set the legend border color, and to set the legend text font.

sect1.title: Axis Controls
sect1.para: The functions in this section control aspects of the X and Y axes. You can control the axis position and optionally use logarithmic scaling.

sect1.title: Grid Controls
sect1.para: The functions in this section control the optional grid drawn behind the plot. You can independently enable the horizontal (Y) and vertical (X) lines in the grid, and use dashed or solid lines.
See also to set the grid color.

note.para: By default, the horizontal (Y) grid is on, and the vertical (X) grid is off.

sect1.title: Labels
sect1.para: The functions in this section control the formatting and display of labels. This includes data labels (text strings which are supplied with the data array), tick labels (automatically generated by PHPlot), and the special labels used on pie charts to show the percentage of each pie slice. Tick labels apply to both X and Y values, while data labels only apply to X values.

sect1.title: Ticks
sect1.para: The functions in this section control the X axis and Y axis tick marks. You can set the tick interval or control the number of ticks, suppress the first or last tick on an axis, and control the tick size.

Left to its own, PHPlot will determine tick values for X and Y axes, but it currently isn't too smart about choosing values and you may not be happy with the results. You can use the functions in this section to set the desired tick interval or number of ticks, but you will most likely also have to call to set the X and/or Y data range limits. Otherwise, you get the tick intervals you want, but the actual values will depend on a somewhat arbitrary base value.

sect1.title: Scaling and Translation
sect1.para: The functions in this section control the overall data scaling and positioning of the plot on the image, or translate coordinates.

sect1.title: Callbacks
sect1.para: The functions in this section are used to implement callbacks. This is an advanced feature described in more detail in .
